title: 107_s888
content: The "College Tuition Assistance Act of 2001" allows for a deduction for higher education expenses under section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This deduction allows individuals to deduct qualified tuition and related expenses paid during the taxable year. The deduction for higher education expenses under the "College Tuition Assistance Act of 2001" is applicable for taxable years 2002 and onwards, with a limit of $5,000 for 2002 and $10,000 for subsequent years. The deduction is subject to a limitation based on modified adjusted gross income, where the amount taken into account is reduced based on the taxpayer's income for the year. The deduction for higher education expenses is limited based on modified adjusted gross income, with thresholds of $50,000 and $100,000 for single and joint filers respectively. Adjustments for inflation are made for these thresholds for taxable years after 2001. The deduction for higher education expenses is limited based on modified adjusted gross income, with thresholds of $50,000 and $100,000 for single and joint filers respectively. Adjustments for inflation are made for these thresholds for taxable years after 2001. Qualified tuition and related expenses are defined as per section 25A(f)(1). Special rules apply. No deduction allowed under subsection (a) for qualified tuition and related expenses without including individual's name and taxpayer identification number on tax return. No double benefit allowed, taxpayer must waive right to deduction under other provisions. No deduction allowed under subsection (a) for qualified tuition and related expenses if taxpayer elects section 25A. No deduction for dependents if deduction under section 151 is allowable to another taxpayer. Deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses only if amount exceeds excludable amount. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is limited to the amount that exceeds the excludable amount under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. The deduction is allowed only for expenses connected to enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year, with certain prepayments allowed for expenses related to an academic term beginning in the taxable year or the first 3 months of the next taxable year. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is limited to the amount that exceeds the excludable amount under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. The amount of qualified tuition and related expenses is reduced by certain scholarships and veterans benefits received by the individual for the taxable year. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is limited to the amount that exceeds the excludable amount under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. It is exempt from income taxation by any law of the United States, and applies only if the taxpayer and spouse file a joint return for the taxable year. Nonresident aliens must be treated as resident aliens of the United States for this deduction to apply. Amendments made by this section apply to expenses paid after December 31, 2001, for education in academic periods beginning after that date. The lifetime learning credit is expanded. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the lifetime learning credit from 20% to 28%. Additionally, there are adjustments made to the AGI limits for the Hope credit, reducing the amount taken into account based on modified adjusted gross income. The lifetime learning credit is increased to 28% from 20% in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Adjustments are made to the AGI limits for the Hope credit, reducing the amount considered based on modified adjusted gross income. The modified adjusted gross income for the taxpayer is calculated based on their adjusted gross income for the taxable year, with certain exclusions. The amendments made to sections 911, 931, and 933 of the Internal Revenue Code pertain to adjustments for scholarships and needs-based aid for qualified expenses. These changes apply to expenses paid after December 31, 2001, for education provided in academic periods starting after that date. Expansion of student loan interest deduction. Expansion of student loan interest deduction includes amending the Internal Revenue Code to allow deductions on qualified education loans per student basis and eliminating the 60-month limit on interest deductions. The effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2001. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code increases income limitation for student loan interest deduction, effective for loan interest paid after December 31, 2001. The income limitation for student loan interest deduction is increased to $80,000 for joint returns, effective after December 31, 2001.
